text: when I make machine learning projects I
don't just upload the source code I also
try to publish a real app but like
nobody else does that and I can kind of
see why first of all most neural network
training and therefore valuation is done
in Python which is not a compiled
language and requires a lot of
installation and technical know-how yes
there's some compiled frameworks out
there but they're a lot harder to set up
and can't possibly support every new or
custom layer type that I might need to
use I mean I ended up writing my own C++
library to get around that but there's
still another issue it's not really a
good idea to run random executables you
download from the internet and your
browser operating system and antivirus
will make sure you know that sure you
can trust me but that doesn't mean
you'll feel comfortable doing it and
lastly I just don't have the time or
resources to cross compile to Mac Linux
Android iOS so I tend to just stick with
Windows which is the most popular the
solution of course is moving everything
to the web but now the problem is I'm
not a web developer and I have very
little experience with backends
front-ends protocols but what if the
server was just a regular linux computer
and I could run all the code I've
already made there and just slap on some
super basic interface to the web enter
Linode it's basically exactly that a
linux server that I have complete
control over and amazingly they agreed
to sponsor this video which was awesome
more about them later so this is how I
got everything working together in only
two weeks again I'm a newbie to this and
I had to learn everything from online
tutorials and googling things besides
buying a domain and signing up for
Linode the first real step was to set up
the DNS and oh my god that was annoying
there's so much terminology and jargon
that just wasn't familiar with luckily
there was a tutorial but it still took
me a couple days to debug a problem
where I accidentally set up my firewall
to blocking everything
whoops but now I need to start making
the big decisions what web server
framework to use and how to interface
with my existing C++ apps after doing a
lot of research this is the framework I
thought would work best for me
I focus on the nginx part first since
that seemed like the biggest unknown so
I followed all the tutorials and made
the modifications I needed to get the
system working and in just a couple of
days I had my hello world now that the
server is running it was surprisingly
easy to take my existing source code
compile it on Linux and connect it to
fast CGI so at this point I've
essentially got my entire back-end float
done so it's time for the front-end
found a nice slider template I liked so
I copied it and it seemed to work great
I added the rest of the sliders and
buttons to the layout and eventually it
was time for the JavaScript to hook
everything together oh boy do I hate
JavaScript no offense if you're into it
but I think it's probably one of the
worst programming languages I've ever
used it's like everything was just
hacked on top of it it's really slow and
it's not very secure yeah anyway after I
was done whining like a baby it wasn't
actually so bad to put together and
after some finishing touches it was all
working all that's left now is a
homepage to link everything together and
deport over some more of my projects to
be fair it's going to run a lot slower
than if you just download the standalone
app since it needs to go through an
internet connection so I'll still be
providing those in the future but now
anyone in the world with an internet
connection can try out my projects and
as a bonus I have my own website now in
fact there's a lot more I could do with
my Linode I could host my own game
server run my own VPN train neural
networks basically if it can run on
Linux it can run on Linode and if you're
interested they'll give you $20 of free
credits if you use this promo code at
checkout I can tell you for my
first-hand experience I really like
their support of open source software
detailed tutorials that I literally
could not do this without and simple
capped pricing where what you see is
what you pay and for the rest of you
neural network enthusiasts they just
launched their new GPU instances with up
to four RT X six thousands some of the
highest end GPUs I've ever seen putting
my 1080 to shame they might seem
expensive but typically you're only
going to use the hourly rate which is a
lot more reasonable than you might think
so huge thanks to Linode check them out
check out my new website and I'll see
you all next time
